fullProgramDescription: The Mechanical Engineering program at UC Berkeley is designed to provide a broad foundation in the principles of mechanical engineering, including the design, analysis, and manufacturing of mechanical systems. The program emphasizes the development of problem-solving skills, creativity, and communication, preparing students for a wide range of careers in industry, government, and academia.
shortProgramDescription: The Mechanical Engineering B.S. program at UC Berkeley provides a comprehensive education in the principles and practices of mechanical engineering, preparing students for diverse careers or graduate study.
classHighlights: The Mechanical Engineering program begins with foundational courses in mathematics and physics, including Calculus (MATH 1A, 1B, 53), Differential Equations (MATH 54), and Physics (PHYSICS 7A, 7B).
Core mechanical engineering courses cover topics such as mechanics (ME 106, ME 108), thermodynamics (ME 100), and mechanical systems (ME 102, ME 131).
Students also complete coursework in materials science (ME 40, ME 143), mechanical design (ME 102, ME 104), and manufacturing processes (ME 104, ME 183).
Additional required courses include Engineering Economics (ME 106), Measurements and Instrumentation (ME 119), and Mechanical Engineering Laboratory (ME 106L).

Electives allow students to explore specialized areas such as biomechanical engineering, energy systems, and robotics, with courses drawn from the mechanical engineering department and related fields.
learningOutcomes: Apply fundamental principles of mechanical engineering to analyze and design mechanical systems.
Demonstrate proficiency in mathematics, physics, and engineering sciences relevant to mechanical engineering.
Design and conduct experiments, and analyze data to inform engineering decisions.
Communicate effectively through written reports, oral presentations, and graphical representations.
Work effectively in teams to solve complex engineering problems.
Understand the social, environmental, and economic contexts of mechanical engineering practice.
additionalInformation: The program includes a comprehensive final examination or project. Students must maintain a minimum GPA in major coursework and adhere to college policies on repeat courses and pass/no pass grading.
